title: Mexico Ratifies Trade Pact with U.S., Canada
summary: Mexican lawmakers vote overwhelmingly in favor of the USMCA, making the nation the first to ratify the accord. MEXICO CITY-Mexico's Senate overwhelmingly voted for a broad rewrite of trade rules between the United States, Canada and Mexico-making the nation the first of the three partners to ratify the pact designed to replace the North American Free Trade Agreement.

title: Rocket Strikes at Site of Foreign Oil Firms in Iraq
summary: Incident is the fourth time in less than a week that rockets have been fired at Iraqi facilities where Americans are stationed. BAGHDAD-A rocket hit a compound in southern Iraq used by Exxon Mobil Corp. and other international oil firms, heightening fears among Iraqi officials that tensions between the U.S. and Iran would spill into their country.

title: PG&E Retires Power Line Blamed for California's Deadliest Wildfire
summary: Inspections have found that the utility needs to make thousands of repairs to its electric system. PG&E Corp. has permanently retired the high-voltage power line that sparked the deadliest wildfire in California's history after detailed inspections of its electric system revealed serious problems on that transmission line and others.

title: Fed Holds Rates Steady, Hints at Cuts if Outlook Doesn't Improve
summary: Central bank's rate-setting panel says it 'will act as appropriate' to sustain an expansion currently clouded by trade fights. WASHINGTON-Federal Reserve officials held interest rates steady on Wednesday but strongly suggested they would cut them in the months ahead if an economic outlook clouded by uncertainty over trade policy didn't improve.

title: A Second Term for What?
summary: Trump can't win by relitigating 2016 and playing only to his base.. President Trump announced his campaign for a second term at a rally in Orlando on Tuesday evening that recounted his first-term record and 2016 victory before thousands of rapturous supporters. The only thing missing was an agenda for 2020.

title: A Split Fed Decision
summary: The Fed can't save the economy from bad trade policy.. The Federal Reserve split the monetary baby on Wednesday, holding the fed-funds rate steady while signaling it's prepared to cut rates if the economic data call for it to "sustain the expansion." That seems like a reasonable call, especially given President Trump's treatment of Chairman Jerome Powell as a political punching bag.

title: EPA Overturns Obama-Era Clean Air Rules for Power Plants
summary: New plan, aimed at boosting coal-fired plants, would limit the agency's ability to mandate tougher greenhouse-gas-emissions regulations. title: 'A Good American Family' Review: Ensnared by the Scare
summary: A thoughtful family history centered on a Midwestern communist's fateful encounter with the House Un-American Activities Committee.. In his latest work of narrative nonfiction, David Maraniss, an editor at the Washington Post and the best-selling biographer of Bill Clinton, Barack Obama and Vince Lombardi, presents a specimen life of the Red Scare era-that of his father, the newspaperman Elliott Maraniss (1918-2004), a veteran of World War II who, in 1952, was named a communist by an FBI informant, subpoenaed by the House Un-American Activities Committee, fired from his job at the Detroit Times, and blacklisted for five years. "He was not falsely accused of being a communist," writes Mr. Maraniss, "because, for a time, he was one. But didn't being a citizen of this country give him the freedom to affiliate with the politics of his choosing and to write and speak his mind, as long as he didn't betray his country as a foreign agent?" In other words, Mr. Maraniss asks, was his father indeed "un-American"? This book is an earnest search for the answer to that question.

title: Accusing the New York Times of 'Treason,' Trump Crosses a Line
summary: The Founders considered it the gravest of crimes. Tossing the charge around is irresponsible and wrong.. First it was "the failing New York Times." Then "fake news." Then "enemy of the people." President Trump's escalating attacks on the New York Times have paralleled his broader barrage on American media. He's gone from misrepresenting our business, to assaulting our integrity, to demonizing our journalists with a phrase that's been used by generations of demagogues.

title: Hunting Elephants Will Help Them Survive
summary: They're magnificent creatures, but Botswana has too many of them in the wrong places.. title: Science Saves an Old Chestnut

In the past century approximately four billion chestnut trees have been lost in the U.S. due to blight that spread when the Cryphonectria parasitica fungus arrived with chestnut trees imported from Asia. A once-dominant hardwood species is now rare.

title: A Fascinating Long Weekend in Detroit: The Essential Guide
summary: How to spend a memorable long weekend in this iconic metropolis, including the buzziest restaurants and music clubs. IN ITS MIDCENTURY boom years, when Motown ruled the airwaves and the big three ruled the roads, Detroit defined America. But, in the subsequent decades, no city fell farther, or harder. Now a much-publicized revival is unfolding there. Downtown is a hive of construction, its sidewalks buzzing with tech-bros and tourists on app-enabled electric scooters (at least until they randomly discard them). Neighborhoods like Midtown (née Cass Corridor) and the West Village are rebounding with ambitious new bars and restaurants, many served by urban farms which have sprouted where houses once stood. Though the hollowing out that made those farms possible is still an issue (the city's population today is just below 700,000, sharply off its 1950s peak of 1.8 million people), rampant development has become an equally pressing concern for many Detroiters. Even the city's industrial ruins, like the old Packard Plant, which have aged into beloved icons for many, are targeted for restoration. The time to appreciate them is now. Taking in everything that Motor City has to offer over the course of a long weekend is challenging. As the T-shirts say, Detroit Hustles Harder. You'll have to adopt the same motto if you want to fit it all in, but feel free to opt out of our ambitious itinerary now and then.

summary: We have worked together to battle this epidemic, and will do whatever it takes to hold Purdue Pharma accountable and get the justice families so deserve.. title: Doctors Should Change the Vaccination Talk
summary: This year's measles outbreak shows that pathogens for which we have vaccines don't disappear; they are around us and ready to infect the nonvaccinated.. The Journal has done a good job covering the recent measles outbreak and the need for vaccination. In "How to Persuade Parents to Vaccinate Their Kids" (op-ed, June 6) Jon LaPook gives useful suggestions to physicians. I suggest another approach: a change in how we talk about the benefits of vaccination. The medical community, the media and the government incorrectly describe vaccines as "eradicating" a disease or "eliminating" a virus. In fact, the vaccines we routinely administer work in two ways. First, they increase an individual's resistance to a pathogen; second, they suppress the spread of a disease by creating "community immunity," but only after about 92% of the population has been immunized.

title: Alexander Hamilton Is Still Relevant Today
summary: "The representatives of the people, in a popular assembly, seem sometimes to fancy that they are the people themselves". title: The Democrats Widen the Abortion Highway
summary: The goal of Democrats is to shut down lanes on the right and open up many new ones on the left. What William Galston may have overlooked in his assessment that "Biden Exits Abortion's Wide Middle Lane" (Politics & Ideas, June 12) is that Democrats are busy widening the abortion highway, so Vice President Joe Biden can swing left and still be in one of the center lanes. title: U.N. Should Determine the Source of the Tanker Attacks
summary: The United Nations should investigate the possibility of false-flag attacks on oil tankers in the Strait of Hormuz.. If Iran wants to warn the world that it could close the Strait of Hormuz, why not just do it? The fact that the culprit in the oil-tanker attacks won't reveal itself suggests that other interested parties may be involved ("U.S. Says Tehran Is to Blame For Attacks on Fuel Tankers," page one, June 14). The face-off between Iran and America is a golden opportunity for Sunni jihadists to launch false-flag terrorist attacks on American or Iranian targets designed to be blamed on the other side. In 2002 al Qaeda damaged the French oil tanker Limburg near the Yemeni coast in a seaborne strike similar to the recent attacks near the Strait of Hormuz.

title: Averages Aren't Always What They Seem
summary: A powerful tool for summarizing data, they can also mislead when their terms aren't made clear.. According to one recent study, 54% of children have below-average reading skills. We often associate the word with the middle of a range of numbers, but in fact there are different types of averages that represent different things.

title: From Collaborations with Wizkid to Album Art with Hailey Bieber, Here's How GoldLink Made "Diaspora" Happen
summary: It's an ambitious idea: getting some of the biggest artists of each continent together on one album. How 26-year-old rapper GoldLink pulled it off-and had Kendall Jenner lend a hand. If Washington, D.C.'s rap scene is having a moment, it's in part thanks to GoldLink. The 26-year-old rapper from the D.C./Maryland/Virginia area started his career rapping over bouncy, more electronic-focused dance beats. In 2017, he released his breakout project At What Cost, a more traditionally rap-rooted mixtape with flourishes of his D.C. upbringing like go-go, a genre of funk specific to the area. The project spawned the Grammy-nominated radio-smash "Crew," which featured fellow regional acts Shy Glizzy and Brent Faiyaz.

title: Facebook COO: 'We Understand' Concerns About Big Tech Companies
summary: Operating chief echoes CEO Mark Zuckerberg's call for regulation, said antitrust action isn't needed to preserve consumer alternatives. CANNES, France- Facebook Inc. title: Slack's Ascent Could Face Some Bumps
summary: Stock may take off Thursday, but slowed growth and limited paying users portend turbulence. title: Number of Displaced People Hits Postwar Record
summary: According to a new U.N. report, nearly 1% of the world's population was displaced at the end of 2018.
